Last Friday, I graduated with my Master of Science in Space Engineering from Caltech! üöÄ

Reflecting on the past nine months, they've been both extremely‚Ä¶ | 67 comments on LinkedIn
data.text:
üöÄ CU Engineering Undergrads: Did you know you can engage in meaningful research to help launch your career, whether you choose industry or academia? Meet Joshua Elston, a senior at University of Colorado Boulder majoring in aerospace engineering. His passion for aerospace was ignited during a family trip to the Kennedy Space Center, leading him to pursue a field that challenges him academically and excites him about the future of space exploration. ü™ê ü¶¨ Joshua chose CU Boulder for its vibrant student atmosphere, highly regarded aerospace program and unique opportunities like the ability to research methods to improve astronaut autonomy in deep space missions. Josh's experience in SPUR (CU Engineering's Summer Program for Undergraduate Research) has not only deepened his knowledge but also opened a pathway toward graduate studies in bioastronautics. Joshua recently presented his research at the Human Research Program Investigators' Workshop (IWS) ‚Äî the primary venue for reporting progress and results of research related to safe, productive and efficient human spaceflight. This experience will help propel Joshua towards his future aspirations which include graduate school and, ultimately, contributing to NASA's efforts in bioastronautics. üßëüèΩüöÄ üî¨ Joshua's story highlights CU Boulder's commitment to providing students with extraordinary research opportunities that help shape future leaders whether they choose industry or academia. Learn more about SPUR and undergraduate research opportunities here: bit.ly/3SWv6sK üîó Deadline to apply to SPUR is March 17! #CUEngineering #AerospaceEngineering #SummerProgram #UndergraduateResearch #Spur #Bioastronautics #HumanSpaceflight #FutureBuffs #FutureGradBuffs #CUBoulderAlumni

https://lnkd.in/ggT2yGxJ via #NASA_APP This grant is from "NASA" to promote scientific projects through "STEM EFFORT"s (Please refer my article on "STEM" that was published quite some time ago in LinkedIn). This grant is exclusively for Educational Institutions in the USA. other World Governments should try to interact and join NASA in propagating STEM projects (curriculum) in their respective Countries. These willing governments should establish a separate department exclusively for this purpose and allocate budget from treasury as well as facilitating NGOs to join hands. Their primary vision is to promote scientific research, mission shall have to be 30 percent of science discipline students should participate every year within 5 years from program start. And the objectives must be supply of equipment, training program and facility for STEM teachers, establishing tied-up curriculum. providing infrastructure at the teaching institutions and setting target plus periodical supervision based on "AI".

üåå University of Florida Launches Space Mission Institute with $2.5M Funding... Big news from the University of Florida (UF)! They are establishing the UF Space Mission Institute, funded by a substantial $2.5 million grant from President Ben Sasse's strategic initiative. This marks a significant stride in space exploration and interdisciplinary research. Key Highlights: ‚ñ™Ô∏è A Hub of Innovation: The institute will function as a collaborative hub, uniting various disciplines like engineering, pharmacy, and liberal arts to revolutionize space travel. ‚ñ™Ô∏è Extensive Research and Collaboration: UF's extensive engagement in space research, including studies on Mars, lunar soil, and habitable planets, will be elevated through this initiative. ‚ñ™Ô∏è Strategic Partnerships: The institute plans to work with the US Space Force and Space Florida, blending space science with defense objectives and offering unique opportunities to ROTC students. üó£Ô∏è "UF's strategic funding initiative will support interdisciplinary seed projects, elevating the university‚Äôs capabilities in space research," says President Ben Sasse. What impact do you foresee this interdisciplinary approach having on the future of space exploration? Let's discuss! https://lnkd.in/ed5ijmse #SpaceMission #UniversityOfFlorida #Innovation #InterdisciplinaryResearch

üì¢ NASA Research Funding Opportunity! üì¢ Early Career Faculty Research Areas: (1) Advanced Propulsion (2) Power Storage on the Moon Audience: Untenured Assistant Professor on the tenure track at the sponsoring U.S. university Funding Level: Max $750k over three years Goal/Intent: ECF is focused on supporting outstanding faculty researchers early in their careers as they conduct space technology research of high priority to NASA‚Äôs Mission Directorates. Eligibility: Accredited U.S. universities are eligible to submit proposals on behalf of their outstanding new faculty members who intend to develop academic careers related to space technology. The Principal Investigator (PI) must be an untenured Assistant Professor on the tenure track at the sponsoring U.S. university at the time of award. See 3 of this Appendix for complete eligibility requirements. Key Important Dates: Release Date: June 12, 2024 Webinar: June 27, 2024 - https://lnkd.in/e_QYxEpS Mandatory Preliminary Proposals Due: July 15, 2024 Mandatory Preliminary Proposal Downselect Date: September 12, 2024 (target) Key Things to note: ‚úî There is a mandatory preliminary proposal requirement that includes a (1) one page summary chart and (2) two page proposal document (excluding citations) ‚úî This funding opportunity uses dual anonymous peer review (DAPR) and proposals must be anonymized. Follow those directions closely! https://lnkd.in/efnwfwT6

A new era of Inclusivity in Science is dawning. NASA, a name synonymous with exploration, has embarked on a journey, not to the stars, but into the realm of open-mindedness and inclusivity. The 'Transform to Open Science' initiative is a testament to their commitment to creating a research culture that is open to all. Their new 101 course is the first step in this direction, providing an introduction to Open Science through definitions, tools, and resources spread across 5 modules. The essence of scientific research is the ability to question, explore, and share knowledge without barriers. By promoting an inclusive culture, we're not just making science more diverse, we're enabling a holistic growth of knowledge. The path to progress is a shared one, and it is initiatives like these that make it a reality. Let's champion inclusivity in every field. Because when we lift each other up, we all rise. Find out more about this course here: https://lnkd.in/ePygt_Jy #science #STEM #inclusivity #openscience #NASA #barriers #culture #champion

üåç Celebrating Earth Day with Our Partners Who Engage Students in Learning about Our Planet üöÄ Virginia Earth System Science Scholars (VESSS) Program: We're proud to partner with the Virginia Space Grant Consortium to support the VESSS program, an immersive initiative engaging high school juniors and seniors in learning about the complexities of Earth's systems through NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's satellite missions. After completing online courses, students are invited to attend a prestigious residential summer academy at NASA Langley Research Center, where they engage in NASA-related research and satellite mission design while connecting directly with NASA scientists, engineers, and technologists, all in an environment deeply rooted in Earth's exploration and understanding. üè´ PLACES (Place-Based Learning to Advance Connections, Education, and Stewardship): We're also privileged to work with WestEd and their NASA-funded PLACES project, focused on engaging students in data-rich, place-based Earth science learning. The project uses a professional learning framework to help teachers cultivate students' sense of place and understanding of earth science concepts using NASA data and data tools. These partnerships exemplify our shared vision of preparing the next generation of earth scientists to use data, data tools, and scientific processes to understand and protect the sustainability of our planet. As we commemorate Earth Day, let's celebrate not only the beauty of our planet but also the remarkable efforts of NASA-funded projects like VESSS and PLACES that are shaping the leaders of tomorrow. #earthday #NASA

Please take a moment & check out the Harvard / MIT / Massachusetts Space Consortium ‚Äî ‚ÄúSpace Week‚Äù is coming up in April 2024! üååüòä ‚ÄúThe Space Consortium was founded in Fall 2017 when a concerted effort supported by the Harvard Provost Office brought together faculty members from Harvard and MIT to work towards a common goal: creating an academic space hub for multidisciplinary space research. Today, the consortium serves a network of over 1,700 affiliates (students, faculty, alumni and space enthusiasts) in the US, working on a wide range of topics‚Ä¶ During Boston Space Week, the Consortium promotes fruitful exchanges between an array of affiliated top experts, business and community leaders, faculty, researchers, educators, students, alumni, and space enthusiasts which allows the community to engage with critical discussions related to the multidisciplinary issues affecting the aerospace industry today. Past speakers have included Jeffrey Hoffman (Former NASA Astronaut and Deputy PI of the Mars MOXIE experiment), Professor Kim Kowal (Chandra X-ray Observatory), Astronaut Soyeon Yi, and Richard Dalbello (VP of Business Development and Government Affairs, Virgin Galactic).‚Äù To become an affiliate and/or participate in Space Week: contact@spaceconsortium.com #space #spaceweek #thespaceconsortium #harvard #mit #aerospace #conference #astronomy #astrophysics #spaceexploration #economy #sustainability #technology #boston #bostonspaceweek #spaceindustry #spacetechnology #education #astrobiology #multidisciplinary #research #festival #community #careerfair

This month, researchers from the University of Brighton are set to run zero-gravity flights to put ground-breaking experimental devices through their paces. The two teams, including six students from participating universities, have just 20 seconds at a time to run tasks in weightless conditions. During each flight, the plane is set to climb to an altitude of 7,500m before going into a 3,000m high roller coaster climb and fall, during which weightlessness is experienced for about 20 seconds. This will be repeated 30 times on each of the three planned parabolic flights later this week. One of the teams is part of the DEPLOY! project, a collaboration between the universities of Brighton, Pisa (Universit√† di Pisa) and Parma (Universit√† degli Studi di Parma) and funded by the UK Space Agency and the European Space Agency - ESA Academy Experiments Programme, which provides funding and support for university students to develop their research in the fields of space science and technology. The other research team taking part, Gell-P, also funded by the UK Space Agency, is pictured below. Read the full story üëá https://lnkd.in/eqJb2pr8
